video_title: Commercialising Space with AI - SuperAI Singapore 2025
description:
Learn more about SuperAI: superai.com
Follow us on X: x.com/superai_conf

Panel: Commercialising Space with AI

Speakers:
Mong Suan Yee, Co-Founder and Director of Engineering @ Kumi Analytics
Jon Wah, Co-Founder @ Nika
Floyd DCosta, Co-Founder and MD @ Space Armour
Rohit Jha, CEO @ Transcelestial

Moderator:
Mark Shmulevich, Advisor to Chairman @ Singapore Space & Technology Think Tank

Stage: io.net Main Stage
#superai #spacetravel #spaceexploration #ai #agi

Recorded on 19 June 2025

transcript.aggregated_text: hey everyone welcome to our exciting panel we have a fantastic uh set of panelists today and I hope thath everyone is fed and you're ready to dive into something very interesting we're going to dive into the intersection of two domains that all of you know about which are AI and space but whose convergence is far less known um there has been many moments in the recent history of AI when artificial intelligence went out of labs and uh became something that people were talking about think about largecale expert systems in the past or the day when uh DBlau won over Kasparov in chess or the recent wave and hype of generative AI which is uh transforming uh how we live and work so much space technologies in turn might also be approaching a pivotal moment there are some indications of that for example uh many things are changing exponentially right now uh for example the number of satellites in orbit has gone up by the factor of 10 over the last years or uh the prohibitive cost of getting the payload to space has plummeted or we have so many startups and commercial companies in space so it feels like that this area is also going to be very very different already in a few years but the question is how can AI uh transform space technology and help it uh become even more usable bring more value to us on Earth and uh unlock new orbits so this is what we're going to talk about today uh we know the names of the panelists but let us start with a proper round of introductions please go one by one and tell us a little bit about uh who you are and what your company does hi I'm Dr imonguan and I'm a co-founder of Kumi Analytics uh Kumi Analytics like uh integrate AI and data uh satellite data uh to uh provide insight of economic and and environmental insights hi everyone my name is John i'm a co-founder of Nika uh which is a spatial computing company based out of Singapore our flagship product is Nikapanet which is essentially a data bricks for geoai uh some of the models type of models our customers build include climate infrastructure um as well as obviously satellite based models from imagery to sensory based models hi guys my name is Floyd Costa and I'm the co-founder of Space Armor we actually started out in cyber security but then since then we've assembled our own AI engine which we are now deploying on an NVIDIA Jetson card and launching it into space exploring uh you know in orbit edge AI use cases we're taking a platform approach but uh for us it's about how can we deliver AI for space in space hi everyone I'm Rohit uh and CEO and co-founder of Trans Celestial we build lasers in space we are using lasers to provide internet worldwide um we're building a giant undersea cable in space uh to power internet worldwide and then also starting next year data centers in space so if you're looking at virtual machines to to put your AI in space give us a shout amazing amazing what a great panel today so I suggest we start from making the whole concept of AI in space less theoretical but much more practical let us show to everyone that there are applications that are happening already right now uh it would be great if if each of you picks just one uh use case uh how you're already using AI how it helps in your business the satellite data is so rich i mean we have data all the way in the 80s and it has the whole world coverage um so our one of our product is SK set it um it is a measurement and validation uh product uh for uh to measure carbon stocks in forest uh before the carbon stock is register as carbon credits and so and so as carbon credits so this this product is um is used even from beginning of the um the project uh where where we work with project developer to to um to choose the project site and choose where the the project developer can measure um uh do ground measurements of the of the forest trees um so we use um satellite for land cover estimation to to identify whether a certain area has been deforested and not and cannot be used for um for the current credits uh project and to uh identify spots where the the ground measurements can be accessible for for measurements we from that we the settle data is very dirty like meaning is you have um atmospheric um uh noise so we do use AI to clean it up we use AI to remove the cloud and shadow and for that we do the measurements there's a lot of features a lot of different data from the satellite data and we fuse it and do the biomass measurements so these are quite a lot of AI that is algorithmic uh AI algorithms that use for for our product uh for us one clear use case uh is actually uh is actually the model our customer built our infrastructure um this is related to some work that they're doing for the Bahamas government where they're actually trying to utilize satellite imagery to actually predict why certain seaggrasses are actually um dying uh in this Bahamas in the Bahamas and the reason is because that's a huge uh importance to the government because that's where a lot of their tourism revenue comes from um so these are the type of models that are trying to predict and and determine why certain seaggrasses might be dying great for us like I mentioned we're taking more of a platform approach so what we have is our entire AI engine which will be hosted in space and I I I guess you know as down on earth we continue to rely more and more on space for a whole lot of services i think that's where we're looking at enabling AI in space just to give an example today if you even look at earth observation a lot of data is collected GBs of data and then sound sent down to earth and processed on the ground our take is that if you can just process that in space then you don't need to send all that data to ground on to the ground but instead of GBs of data you just send the 1 M of the 5 MB file for example that's what's really required the other case is also it goes stretches beyond if you look at climate impact or disaster warning systems again instead of sending that data down to ground and processing it and trying to uh trigger alerts you can process that in space itself and take away all the lag and the and latency and instantly broadcast threat alerts thereby trying you know being able to more efficiently basically deliver warnings to uh prevent loss of life or property just a few example but then it goes even beyond defense and further out there yeah um I just very quick there's three ways we use AI uh one is on a on a device level AI allows us to uh different kinds of machine intelligence but it allows us to beam lasers very accurately at long distances so for example last year we be beamed lasers from LA all the way to Palm Springs to provide internet for Coachella Music Festival so if you guys were streaming 4K videos of Coachella that was thanks to us second uh national uh sovereignity is not guaranteed anymore we have three major battles going on and bulk of that battle is being fought on the intelligence front and we are not talking about traditional intelligence with machine intelligence so one of our use cases is how um how our non-jamable communications which we use as lasers can effectively allow uh ship swarms and drone swarms to protect your borders to protect your citizens but also deter any kind of forces that want to take that sovereignity away and the final one is uh space transelestial as the name suggests uh we believe that humanity's v future is in the stars and we are building the telecommunication systems for us to go deeper to send one noman pure probes or similar kind of machine intelligence in deep space what is extremely critical to make that happen is data centers and connectivity and so it it's kind of like a mix and match of where we use AI and what kind of intelligences we use some are dumb AI some are smart AI but yeah it offers a lot of open uh capabilities to us yeah thank you thank you great um I feel there are so many uh use cases and the the whole range from incremental improvement of what you do anyway to unlocking new use cases is there but uh applying AI in the business environment is uh in your work and if yes how do you overcome it uh yes definitely so we use Google uh cloud and um and AWS they have all the data set in their cloud storage um so so we can search the relevant data um some of the problems we have is the quality of the data that we use to train a model like um sometimes some data are not available like uh when the cloud and shadow is the missing data data and also make decisions have the latest information and context not just the the large language model at the back end which they're using to take the decision so it's not just guardrails and things like that incentive to run things on prem or on your server has gone away pretty much but the other side of the market which is I would argue orders of magnitude bigger and what we play in is defense national here to understand how can you deliver better cost per serve and latency per serve to private customers like governments and defense which want to run these models inside their firewall inside on the classic challenge when you put an IoT sensor how much do you collect at the edge and how much do you process versus how much do you send back and process at the center this has been a very classic back and forth so in space what's happening is all the earth observation all the military satellites they strike a balance between how much data they collect and how much they compute on board with uh more high bandwidth laser coms and data centers in space what's going to happen is they're going to offload all of that to centralized uh GPU clusters and stuff in space but there's two major challenges so very quickly what you would see Mark is um us getting to shifting compute and storage capabilities on centralized nodes like we did on earth but unlike on earth we have two major problems in space one is sun sun's energy is extremely weak and so we have to within we'll get to five to 10 kilowatts of data centers and then we will have a plateau there for a while until we can put small modular nuclear reactors and antimatter reactors up there so once you get that then you break the 50 megawatt barrier and you can start putting more stuff up there the second problem is heat space is cold but it's infinitely harder to cool things down in space because there is no air and so what do you do with that all of that additional heat which is already a problem for data centers here so there's a lot of cool innovations coming from on how to handle and handle that but I think these two are going to be we're going to quickly get quick benefits and we'll deploy some AI
